<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
ETRIP credits years of executive service only beginning with 1995.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>In
accordance with applicable SEC rules, dollar amounts in this column were computed on December&nbsp;31, 2007, which was the WaMu Pension Plan measurement date used
for financial statement reporting purposes with respect to our audited financial statements for 2007. For purposes of this table, we assume a retirement age of 65, the normal retirement age in the
WaMu Pension Plan. Furthermore, we assume a benefit payment date for the ETRIP that is the earlier of age 62 and 5&nbsp;years of executive service or age 65. Further information on how theses
amounts were calculated is given in the narrative below.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>(3)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
named executives were vested in the ETRIP as of the end of 2007 in the following amounts: Mr.&nbsp;Killinger: 80%, Mr.&nbsp;Casey: 80%, Mr.&nbsp;Rotella: 40%,
Mr.&nbsp;Corcoran: 20%, Mr.&nbsp;Cathcart: 40%, and Ms.&nbsp;Chapman: 80%. Had the named executives been terminated on December&nbsp;31, 2007 for any reason other than cause, as defined in the
plan, the ETRIP benefits for each named executive as of such date would have been as follows: Mr.&nbsp;Killinger: $4,163,078, Mr.&nbsp;Casey: $1,293,336, Mr.&nbsp;Rotella: $959,290,
Mr.&nbsp;Corcoran: $103,497, Mr.&nbsp;Cathcart: $159,719, and Ms.&nbsp;Chapman: $1,423,695. The ETRIP generally defines "cause" for this purpose as fraud, embezzlement, theft or any other crime
of moral turpitude or dishonesty in the executive's relationship with the Company (without necessity of formal criminal proceedings being initiated). </FONT></DD></DL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Cash Balance Pension Plan  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our cash balance defined benefit plan, the WaMu Pension Plan, provides that participants receive benefit credit accruals as a percentage of eligible compensation
and interest accruals on current and prior benefit accruals. The current benefit accrual rate is based on years of service as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>for
benefit service less than five years, the benefit credit is 4.0%; </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>114</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=117,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=156351,FOLIO='114',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EI10601A.;12',USER='DHOLBRO',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ei10601_1_115"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>for
benefit service from five to less than ten years, the benefit credit is 5.0%;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>for
benefit service from ten to less than fifteen years, the benefit credit is 6.0%;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>for
benefit service from fifteen to less than twenty years, the benefit credit is 7.0%; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>for
twenty years or more of benefit service, the benefit credit is 8.0%. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Eligible
compensation includes base salary, cash incentive payments, bonuses and overtime, up to the annual compensation limitation contained in Section&nbsp;401(a)(17) of the Internal
Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the "</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Code</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>"), and less any deferrals by the executive into our Deferred Compensation Plan. The WaMu Pension Plan
credits interest on all cash balance benefit accruals at the annual rate quoted at the beginning of each year for the average annual yield on U.S. government securities of a constant maturity of
30&nbsp;years for all business days during the prior November. The Pension Plan credits benefit accruals each pay period and interest on a daily basis, and the annual interest credit rate for 2007
was 4.69%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
general, all employees, including the named executives, become eligible to participate in the WaMu Pension Plan beginning with the quarter following completion of one year of service
with the Company during which they work a minimum of 1,000&nbsp;hours. An employee's cash balance in the WaMu Pension Plan becomes vested at a graduated rate after two years of service, with full
vesting after five years of active service, except that eligible employees who first began employment after December&nbsp;31, 2005, vest after five years of service with no graduated vesting.
Employees accruing at least one hour of service after December&nbsp;31, 2007 will be 100% vested after three years of service. There are no employee contributions to the WaMu Pension Plan. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon
termination, participants may elect to receive a lump sum distribution of their vested cash balances or an annuitized payment from the WaMu Pension Plan's trust fund. The WaMu
Pension Plan is designed to comply with the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended (ERISA). </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
WaMu Pension Plan Present Value of Accumulated Benefits reported in the table above was calculated as follows: for each named executive, the cash balance benefit as of
December&nbsp;31, 2007 was projected to age 65 using an assumed long-term interest crediting rate of 5.40% with no probability of death assumed before age 65. The present value of this
projected benefit is established using the same demographic and economic assumptions we used in our audited financial statements contained in our Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. The present value is then discounted back to December&nbsp;31, 2007, using the financial statement discount rate assumption of 6.40% with no probability of death
assumed before age 65. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Executive Target Retirement Income Plan  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2004 we established the ETRIP to provide retirement benefits for our executive officers, including the named executives. The ETRIP replaced the Supplemental
Executive Retirement Accumulation Plan (the "</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>SERAP</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>"), discussed below, for our executive officers. The ETRIP was designed to provide a market
competitive retirement benefit for participants. The ETRIP provides supplemental retirement benefits that, as a lump sum, are equal to 6.5 times a participant's average base salary and bonus during
the last five calendar years (excluding compensation for years during which the participant was ineligible under the plan), reduced proportionally for executive service of less than 25&nbsp;years.
For this purpose, only executive service beginning with 1995 and beyond is considered. This benefit is offset by a participant's vested balances in our Supplemental Employees' Retirement Plan (the
"</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>SERP</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>"), the SERAP, the WaMu Pension Plan, and our contributions for that employee to our 401(k) plan. Benefits under the ETRIP vest in 20% increments
over five years, counting only full years of executive service on or after January&nbsp;1, 2004. Upon a change-in-control of the Company, each participant would receive an
additional three years of service credit, depending on the participant's </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>115</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=118,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=7186,FOLIO='115',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EI10601A.;12',USER='DHOLBRO',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ei10601_1_116"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>existing
change-in-control or employment agreement with us. In addition, our or a successor company's ability to amend the ETRIP after a
change-in-control is strictly prohibited, except to provide for additional offsets for any retirement plans adopted after a change-in-control. In
compliance with Section&nbsp;409A of the Code, six months after termination of employment, each participant receives a lump sum payment equal to his or her balance, except that any participant may
make an irrevocable election at least one year before the distribution to receive annual installments over a period of up to 20&nbsp;years so long as the participant's plan balance exceeds $500,000
at the time of termination. Anyone who does not make an election will receive a lump sum payment at least six months after termination of employment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
ETRIP Present Value of Accumulated Benefits reported in the table above is calculated as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>For
each named executive, the average base salary and bonus during the last five calendar years with our Company (excluding compensation for years during which the named
executive was ineligible under the plan) is multiplied by 6.5 and is designated the "target benefit."
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>This
target benefit is multiplied by the months of executive service (capped at 300) with a full month credited in the first month as a Company executive, regardless of the
actual day within the first month of the executive designation, and then divided by 300. For example, an executive who has been with us for two years would receive 24&nbsp;months of executive
service, which means that he or she would have 8% of the total executive service possible under the plan.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>This
lump sum benefit is assumed payable at the earlier of age 62 with 60&nbsp;months of executive service, or age 65.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
vesting schedule of 20% per projected completed year of executive service at the benefit payment date is then applied and this final amount is the maximum lump sum that
is payable from the ETRIP. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Offsets to the Maximum Lump Sum Payable under the Executive Target Retirement Income Plan  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Once the maximum lump sum is determined, offsets are calculated, and the ETRIP benefit is reduced by the amount of our contributions or credits to our other
retirement plans, as described below. The ETRIP amounts reported in the table above reflect applicable offsets pursuant to the plan. As offsets, the following amounts are subtracted from the maximum
ETRIP amount as calculated above: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>As
applicable, each named executive's Company-provided benefit (including earnings thereon) in the WaMu Savings Plan as of December&nbsp;31, 2007, projected to the assumed
benefit payment date at a compound per annum rate of 7%.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>As
applicable, each named executive's benefit in the WaMu Pension Plan as of December&nbsp;31, 2007, projected to the assumed benefit payment date at a compound per annum
rate of 4.70%.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>As
applicable, each named executive's benefit in the SERP as of December&nbsp;31, 2007, projected to the assumed benefit payment date at a compound per annum rate of
4.70%.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>As
applicable, each named executive's benefit in the SERAP as of December&nbsp;31, 2007, projected to the assumed benefit payment date at a compound per annum rate of
5.48%. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
each named executive, the remaining ETRIP benefit after subtracting each applicable component described above is discounted back from the assumed payment date to December&nbsp;31,
2007, using the same 5.70% discount rate contained in our 2007 financial statements and ignoring mortality before the assumed payment date. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>116</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=119,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=61619,FOLIO='116',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EI10601A.;12',USER='DHOLBRO',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ei10601_1_117"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Amounts
shown in the "Present Value of Accumulated Benefits" column in the table above are the actuarial present values of the December&nbsp;31, 2007 accumulated benefits. These
amounts do not correspond to actual amounts that would have been payable upon termination on December&nbsp;31, 2007. For information on amounts payable to the named executives under the ETRIP upon
termination on December&nbsp;31, 2007, see footnote 3 to the Pension Benefits Table at page&nbsp;114 above. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed above, in January 2008 the Human Resources Committee approved amendments to the ETRIP to exclude from participation new named executives hired or otherwise made eligible
after January&nbsp;1, 2008. The Committee approved an amendment to the plan providing that, effective December&nbsp;31, 2012, participants will cease to accrue employment service credits for
benefits and vesting purposes, except in the case of a change-in-control, in which case participants would continue to receive an additional three years of service credit. In
connection with this amendment, the Committee also approved other amendments affecting the benefit calculation formula. Effective December&nbsp;31, 2012, benefits for each participant no longer will
be reduced by (i)&nbsp;Company contributions or credits the participant receives under our other general and executive retirement benefit plans and the WaMu Savings Plan, or (ii)&nbsp;the effects
of decreases in base salary and bonus during the five-year measurement period. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>117</FONT></P>

<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

NAME="page_ek10601_1_118"> </A>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->


 </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>2007 Nonqualified Deferred Compensation  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We offer two nonqualified defined contribution plans&#151;the Deferred Compensation Plan and the SERP&#151;to the named executives. Both of these
plans are described in detail below. In addition, certain highly compensated employees, not including the named executives or other executive officers, participate in the SERAP. Before our adoption of
the ETRIP in 2004, some of our executive officers, including the named executives, were eligible to receive benefit accruals in the SERAP based on age and service requirements then in effect under the
plan. Mr.&nbsp;Killinger and Ms.&nbsp;Chapman are the only named executives who have an existing SERAP account benefit, which continues to receive interest credits but not further benefit
accruals. No other named executive had any SERAP benefit when the executive officer benefit accruals ended in 2004. Mr.&nbsp;Casey elected to receive the withdrawal shown in the table below from the
Deferred Compensation Plan at the time of his initial deferral election. </FONT></P>

(described below) and the significant decline in our stock price during 2007.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(4)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Mr.&nbsp;Killinger

<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(5)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>As
of December&nbsp;31, 2007, each named executive is vested in his or her SERP benefit reported above as follows: Mr.&nbsp;Killinger: 100%, Mr.&nbsp;Casey: 100%,
Mr.&nbsp;Rotella: 50%, Mr.&nbsp;Corcoran: 0%, Mr.&nbsp;Cathcart: 25%, Ms.&nbsp;Chapman: 100%. Of the amounts shown, the following amounts were reported in the Summary Compensation Table in our
definitive proxy </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>118</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=121,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=490345,FOLIO='118',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EK10601A.;12',USER='DHOLBRO',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ek10601_1_119"> </A>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>statement
filed March&nbsp;19, 2007 (the "2007 Summary Compensation Table"), which was our first proxy statement filed under the SEC's new executive compensation disclosure rules:
Mr.&nbsp;Killinger: $346,800, Mr.&nbsp;Casey: $68,142, Mr.&nbsp;Rotella: $18,200. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(6)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>$1,885,680
of this amount was reported as part of Mr.&nbsp;Rotella's 2006 compensation in the 2007 Summary Compensation Table. </FONT></DD></DL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Deferred Compensation Plan  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We maintain a nonqualified unsecured Deferred Compensation Plan that allows certain highly compensated employees, including the named executives, to defer
compensation. The amounts deferred into this plan and all earnings remain subject to claims of our general creditors until distributed upon a date or event selected by the participant. Eligible
employees may elect to defer regular pay, bonuses, gains on exercise of nonqualified stock options, compensation related to the lapse of restrictions on restricted stock, and issuance of common stock
or cash in satisfaction of performance share awards. Plan account balances are credited with earnings based on a participant's selection of one or more of the following methods: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Interest Method.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;This method credits interest at a rate equal to the rate at which unsecured junior debt would
be issued. If we did not issue any unsecured junior debt for the year, then the comparable rate for peer institutions is used. We establish this rate on September&nbsp;30 of the previous year (2007
interest rate: 5.83%).
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Phantom Stock.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;This method tracks the performance of our common stock (2007 rate of return: (68.25%)).
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Vanguard Institutional Index Fund.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;This fund tracks the performance of the Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's 500 Index
(2007 rate of return: 5.5%).
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Vanguard Small-Cap Index Fund.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;This fund tracks the Morgan Stanley Capital International
("</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>MSCI</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>") U.S. Small Cap 1750 Index (2007 rate of return: 1.29%).
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Vanguard Developed Markets Index Fund.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;This fund tracks the MSCI Europe and Pacific Region Index (2007 rate of
return: 10.99%). </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
rates of return for these earnings methods (other than the Interest Method) may be positive or negative and thus may result in gains or losses to a participant's plan balance. At the
time of deferral of any item of compensation, each participant elects the payment commencement date, the earnings accrual method, and the form of payment. The earnings accrual method may be changed by
the participant no more than one time per month. Available forms of payment are either lump sum or, if the participant's balance exceeds $100,000, installment payments for a period of up to ten years.
We do not make any contributions into the plan on behalf of participants or match any amounts deferred pursuant to the plan, other than dividend equivalents for balances with earnings accrual credits
based on the Phantom Stock method. In compliance with Section&nbsp;409A of the Code, the payment election must be made at least one year before the distribution. In accordance with applicable SEC
rules, we reported compensation deferred into the plan as compensation to the named executive for the year earned. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2007, under the transition rules of Internal Revenue Code Section&nbsp;409A, we allowed participants to make a one-time election to accelerate distributions of
previously deferred compensation. This one-time election provided for payments of a lump sum or up to ten annual installments for those whose balance exceeded $100,000. Lump sum or
installment payments will begin in July 2008. Of the named executives, Messrs.&nbsp;Killinger and Casey and Ms.&nbsp;Chapman chose to accelerate payment of their full balances in the plan. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>119</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=122,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=303153,FOLIO='119',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EK10601A.;12',USER='DHOLBRO',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ek10601_1_120"> </A>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Supplemental Employees' Retirement Plan  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The SERP is a non-qualified plan designed to provide certain highly compensated employees, including the named executives, with benefits they would
have otherwise received under the WaMu Pension Plan, but for certain restrictions set forth in the Code on the amount of compensation that may be considered as eligible compensation pursuant to the
Pension Plan. The SERP is designed to provide participants with a benefit credit equal to the benefit credit they would have received under the Pension Plan (between 4% and 8%, depending on their
years of service) had their eligible compensation under the Pension Plan not been limited by applicable restrictions contained in the Code. In addition, an individual's SERP benefit vests over a
five-year period and is credited with earnings at an annual rate that is established in the same manner as the Pension Plan rate discussed above. We establish the rate on
November&nbsp;30 of the prior year, and during 2007 the applicable interest rate for this plan was 4.52%. In compliance with Section&nbsp;409A of the Code, six months after termination of service
for a participant who is a "specified" or "key" employee under Section&nbsp;409A, the participant will receive a lump sum payment equal to his or her total benefit, except that any participant with
a total benefit in excess of $100,000 may elect to receive annual installment payments over a period of up to ten years, if in accordance with Section&nbsp;409A of the Code, the election is made at
least one year before the distribution. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Supplemental Executive Retirement Accumulation Plan  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The SERAP is a non-qualified plan designed to provide additional retirement benefits to the named executives and other executive officers. Prior to
our adoption of the ETRIP in 2004, our executive officers, including the named executives, were eligible to receive benefit accruals under the SERAP based on a combination of age and service credits.
None of the named executives receives any benefit accruals pursuant to the SERAP; however Mr.&nbsp;Killinger's SERAP benefit continues to receive interest credits. Pursuant to the SERAP,
participants receive benefit credits of 1% for each year of Company executive service, with a minimum of 3% and a maximum of 12%. Participants also receive an interest credit based on the rate that
would have been paid on our unsecured junior debt (if any) with a ten-year maturity. If we did not issue any unsecured junior debt for the year, then the comparable rate for peer
institutions is used. We establish this rate during September of the previous year and for 2007, the applicable interest rate for this plan was 5.83%. The same distribution restrictions under
Section&nbsp;409A described for the SERP above also apply to the SERAP. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Deferred Bonus Arrangement  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pursuant to his 1982 employment agreement with a company we acquired, Mr.&nbsp;Killinger is entitled to a deferred bonus arrangement that we assumed, pursuant
to which certain of Mr.&nbsp;Killinger's deferred bonus amounts and accrued earnings payable to him by the predecessor company are payable by us to Mr.&nbsp;Killinger upon termination of his
employment for any reason. Company credits are no longer made to this account and the balance is treated as having been invested in the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Principal Funds Equity Income I
(A)&nbsp;Fund</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. The rate of return on this account during 2007 was 4.72%, and as of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the accrued benefits under this arrangement totaled $352,170. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Potential Payments Upon Termination or Change-in-Control  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This section discusses the incremental compensation we would have to pay to each named executive in the event of a change-in-control of
the Company or a termination of the named executive's employment with us for various described reasons, sometimes referred to in this section as a "triggering event." In accordance with applicable SEC
rules, the following discussion assumes: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>that
the triggering event in question&#151;the death, disability, change-in-control or termination&#151;occurred on December&nbsp;31,
2007, the last business day of 2007; and </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>120</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=123,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=319675,FOLIO='120',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EK10601A.;12',USER='DHOLBRO',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ek10601_1_121"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>with
respect to calculations based on our stock price, we used $13.61, which was the reported closing price of one share of our common stock on the NYSE on
December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
connection with any actual termination of employment, we may determine to enter into an agreement or to establish an arrangement providing additional benefits or amounts, or altering
the terms of benefits described below, as deemed appropriate by the Human Resources Committee. The actual amounts that would be paid upon a named executive's termination of employment can be
determined only at the time of such executive's separation from the Company. Due to the number of
factors that affect the nature and amount of any benefits provided upon the events discussed below, any actual amounts paid or distributed may be higher or lower than reported below. Factors that
could affect these amounts include the timing during the year of any such event, our stock price and the executive's age and service. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Various
agreements and plans define each named executive's rights and obligations in the event of a triggering event. Specifically, each named executive other than Ms.&nbsp;Chapman is
a party to an agreement with us called either an "employment agreement" or a "change-in-control agreement", and each named executive is a party to equity award agreements, and
each is or may be a participant in various Company plans, including, without limitation, the Amended and Restated 2003 Equity Incentive Plan, the ETRIP, the SERP, the SERAP, the Leadership Bonus Plan
and the new executive severance plan discussed at page&nbsp;100. Ms.&nbsp;Chapman is a party to a severance agreement, discussed at page&nbsp;101. These agreements and plans may provide that a
named executive is entitled to additional consideration in the event of a triggering event. The change-in-control agreements of Messrs.&nbsp;Casey, Corcoran and Cathcart do
not provide any material benefits or compensation to either named executive prior to a change-in-control of the Company; however, our new executive severance plan adopted in
2008 does. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following is a general discussion of the primary categories of triggering events under the named executives' employment or change-in-control agreements and
Company plans. Where the terms and consequences are unique with respect to a particular named executive, the differences are discussed in the footnotes to the table below for that named executive. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the footnotes to the tables that follow this discussion, we also disclose the aggregate amount of vested other compensation each named executive could have realized if his or her
employment terminated on December&nbsp;31, 2007, regardless whether a triggering event occurred. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Death or Disability  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The employment or change-in-control agreements we have with all named executives other than Ms.&nbsp;Chapman generally provide that we
shall make no further cash payments to the named executive, or his estate, in the event of death or disability. Under Ms.&nbsp;Chapman's severance agreement, upon this triggering event
Ms.&nbsp;Chapman would be entitled to receive all cash payments due to her under her severance agreement and related consulting agreement. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon
death or disability, all of a named executive's unvested equity shall immediately vest as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>All
unvested stock options vest and remain exercisable until the first to occur of (i)&nbsp;12&nbsp;months after the date of death or permanent disability or
(ii)&nbsp;the original expiration date of the option.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>All
shares of restricted stock become vested to the extent of our achievement of the applicable Company performance measures for such shares (if any) as of the end of the
relevant period.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>With
respect to performance share awards, the named executive or his or her estate receives a prorated award based on the number of weeks of employment during the
performance period and prior to the triggering event. This is paid out at the end of the applicable performance cycle to the extent of our achieved performance relative to the peer group. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>121</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=124,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=173823,FOLIO='121',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EK10601A.;12',USER='DHOLBRO',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ek10601_1_122"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon
death or disability, cash bonuses payable to a named executive under our Leadership Bonus Plan are prorated based on the number of days of active service during the calendar year
prior to the triggering event. Our performance continues to be measured against the applicable performance measures at the end of the applicable calendar year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Each
named executive, or his or her beneficiaries, will receive payments or benefits under our Deferred Compensation Plan, SERP, SERAP and ETRIP, to the extent of their balances or
accrued benefits, pursuant to the terms of those plans. These plans and the named executives' plan balances or accrued amounts, as applicable, are described in detail beginning at page&nbsp;114. In
general, each of these plans provides for the payment of a lump sum to the named executive or his or her estate if his or her balance is under a threshold amount, or installment payments under certain
circumstances. Between the date of the applicable triggering event and the date benefits are distributed, each named executive's benefits under these plans continue to accrue earnings, and, with
respect to the Deferred Compensation Plan, are adjusted by gains or losses based upon his or her investment elections. The benefits under these plans, other than the Deferred Compensation Plan, vest
over an established schedule. The SERP and SERAP provide for an acceleration of the unvested balance upon the death or permanent disability of the executive, while the ETRIP provides no acceleration
under those circumstances. In the employment or change-in-control agreement for each named executive other than Ms.&nbsp;Chapman, "termination due to disability" is generally
defined as the named executive being unable to perform the essential functions of his job for a continuous period of 180&nbsp;days. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Termination of Employment by the Company without "Cause" before a Change-in-Control of the Company  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Messrs.&nbsp;Killinger and Rotella have employment agreements that provide for compensation payments and equity acceleration if we terminate their employment
without "cause," as defined below, before there is a change-in-control of the Company. As discussed at page&nbsp;100, in January 2008 the Human Resources Committee approved
the material terms of a new executive severance plan in which Messrs.&nbsp;Casey, Corcoran and Cathcart will participate. Ms.&nbsp;Chapman will not participate in the new plan because she is no
longer an executive officer. For purposes of this discussion and the tables that follow, we have assumed the new executive severance plan was effective as of December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Equity Acceleration&#151;Messrs.&nbsp;Killinger and Rotella  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If we terminate Mr.&nbsp;Killinger or Mr.&nbsp;Rotella without cause and before a change-in-control of the Company, he would be
entitled to equity acceleration as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>All
unvested stock options and unvested shares of restricted stock would vest.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Mr.&nbsp;Rotella's
performance share awards would continue for the remainder of the performance cycles pursuant to his employment agreement. Because he is over age 55 and
has over 10&nbsp;years of service, Mr.&nbsp;Killinger would not forfeit his performance share awards. In both cases, the payout of performance share awards, if any, would be made at the end of the
applicable performance cycle to the extent of our achieved performance relative to its peer group. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Cash Payments&#151;Messrs.&nbsp;Killinger and Rotella  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Both Mr.&nbsp;Killinger and Mr.&nbsp;Rotella would be entitled to a lump sum cash severance payment six months after the date of termination.
Mr.&nbsp;Killinger's severance amount would be equal to three times his
"annual compensation" and Mr.&nbsp;Rotella's severance would equal two times his "annual compensation." For this purpose, "annual compensation" includes only the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Salary
and bonus, calculated as: (i)&nbsp;the greatest of the executive's annual base salary for (A)&nbsp;the calendar year in which termination occurs, (B)&nbsp;the
prior calendar year, or (C)&nbsp;(if applicable) the </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>122</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=125,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=462374,FOLIO='122',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EK10601A.;12',USER='DHOLBRO',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ek10601_1_123"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>calendar
year immediately preceding the year in which the change-in-control occurred, plus (ii)&nbsp;the greatest of (A)&nbsp;the executive's unadjusted target bonus for
the calendar year in which the termination occurs, (B)&nbsp;the executive's actual bonus (including, for the avoidance of doubt, any portion of the actual bonus that was deferred or exchanged at the
executive's election for equity awards) for the prior calendar year, or (C)&nbsp;if applicable, the executive's actual bonus (including, for the avoidance of doubt, any portion of the actual bonus
that was deferred or exchanged at the executive's election for equity awards) for the calendar year immediately preceding the year in which the change-in-control occurred; </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Benefit
accruals made (or anticipated to have been made during the remainder of the year) on behalf of the named executive under the WaMu Pension Plan and the SERP, and
Company contributions on behalf of the named executive under the WaMu Savings Plan during the calendar year in which the termination occurs; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
annualized contributions made on behalf of the named executive under our medical, dental, life and long-term disability plans during the calendar year in
which the termination occurs. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
the Committee's discretion, cash bonus payments pursuant to our Leadership Bonus Plan would be prorated based on the number of days of active service during the calendar year prior to
the termination. Company performance continues to be measured against the applicable performance measures at the end of the applicable calendar year. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Cash Payments&#151;Other Named Executives  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under our new executive severance plan, all executive officers other than Messrs.&nbsp;Killinger and Rotella, including Messrs.&nbsp;Casey, Corcoran and
Cathcart, are entitled to a cash payment upon this triggering event equal to 1.5 times the sum of (i)&nbsp;base salary plus (ii)&nbsp;the higher of (A)&nbsp;target bonus for the current year or
(B)&nbsp;actual bonus for the prior year. No benefits under the severance plan will be paid to any covered executive who becomes entitled to benefits under his or her
change-in-control agreement. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under
Ms.&nbsp;Chapman's severance agreement, upon this triggering event Ms.&nbsp;Chapman would be entitled to receive all payments due to her under her severance agreement and
related consulting agreement. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Termination by Company with "Cause" or by the Named Executive for Any Reason before a Change-in-Control of the Company  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our employment or change-in-control agreements with all named executives other than Ms.&nbsp;Chapman, and the new executive severance
plan, provide that if we terminate the named executive with "cause" before there is a change-in-control of the Company, then the named executive would not be entitled to any
cash severance payments. If Ms.&nbsp;Chapman materially breaches the terms of her severance agreement or related consulting agreement at any time whether before or after a
change-in-control of the Company, then she would not be entitled to any further payments under either agreement. In addition, in case of a "for cause" termination, all of each
named executive's outstanding stock options (whether vested or unvested), unvested shares of restricted stock and performance share awards for outstanding performance cycles would be immediately
forfeited and cancelled pursuant to the applicable equity award agreements. The named executive's cash bonus payout under our Leadership Bonus Plan for the year in which the termination occurred would
be forfeited at the discretion of the Human Resources Committee. The employment and change-in-control agreements generally define "cause" to include (i)&nbsp;recurring
violations of our substance abuse policy; (ii)&nbsp;conviction of a felony or certain misdemeanors involving moral turpitude; (iii)&nbsp;entering into a pretrial diversion program in connection
with the prosecution for certain crimes; (iv)&nbsp;dishonesty, fraud, destruction or </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>123</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=126,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=567122,FOLIO='123',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EK10601A.;12',USER='DHOLBRO',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ek10601_1_124"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>theft
of Company property; (v)&nbsp;physical attack on another Company employee; (vi)&nbsp;willful malfeasance or gross negligence in performance; or (vii)&nbsp;or misconduct that causes a
material injury to us. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
plan documents for our nonqualified retirement plans, the SERP, SERAP and ETRIP, all generally provide that if the "for cause" termination of the named executive is due to his or her
fraud,
embezzlement, theft or any other crime of moral turpitude or dishonesty in his or her relationship with us (without necessity of formal criminal proceedings being initiated), then the named
executive's vested and unvested benefits in these plans also would be forfeited. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If
the named executive terminates his or her employment for any reason prior to a change-in-control, the employment and change-in-control
agreements and plan documents (and severance and consulting agreements for Ms.&nbsp;Chapman) do not provide for any additional compensation or benefits for such named executive. However, the named
executive would not forfeit his or her equity awards and retirement plan balances, as described above. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Upon a Change-in-Control of the Company without Termination of the Named Executive's Employment  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The named executives' employment and change-in-control agreements and Ms.&nbsp;Chapman's severance and consulting agreements do not
provide for any additional compensation payable to the named executives in the event of a change-in-control of the Company
(</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>e.g.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, no "single trigger" payment). However, our Amended and Restated 2003 Equity Incentive Plan provides that as of the consummation of a "company
transaction," all outstanding unvested stock options and unvested shares of restricted stock would vest, unless the Human Resources Committee instead in its discretion provides that such outstanding
awards are assumed or substituted by the acquiring company with all existing terms and conditions, including vesting terms, remaining in effect. For this purpose, "company transaction" is generally
defined in the Plan as an acquisition of the Company by merger, consolidation, asset acquisition or stock purchase, which is generally the same as a change-in-control of the
Company. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of the closing of the change-in-control (whether or not the named executive is later terminated), the named executives would receive a payout for all
performance share awards subject to outstanding performance cycles. The payout would be based on our performance relative to the peer group, as calculated through the most recent month or quarter
prior to the date of the change-in-control. In addition, our ETRIP provides that each named executive would be credited with three additional years of "executive service" for
the purposes of ETRIP benefit calculations. The SERP and SERAP do not have any acceleration or similar provisions regarding a change-in-control. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Within Three Years after a Change-in-Control of the Company: Termination by the Company for Any Reason or without Cause, as Applicable, or by the Named Executive with Good
Reason  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with their employment or change-in-control agreements and applicable benefit plan documents, each named executive other than
Ms.&nbsp;Chapman would receive the amounts described in the section entitled "Death or Disability" with any performance criteria related to restricted stock vesting removed, as well as a lump sum
cash severance payment equal to three times the named executive's "annual compensation" in the event that they are terminated for any reason (for Messrs.&nbsp;Killinger and Rotella) or without cause
(for Messrs.&nbsp;Casey, Corcoran and Cathcart) or if they terminate their employment with "good reason," in all cases within three years after a change-in-control of the
Company. For this purpose, annual compensation would be calculated in accordance with the description above at page&nbsp;122. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
Messrs.&nbsp;Killinger and Rotella, "good cause" or "good reason" is generally defined as any of the following: (i)&nbsp;assignment of duties that are materially different from
those assigned prior to the change-in-control, or which result in significantly less authority and responsibility; (ii)&nbsp;the removal of named executive from the position
held immediately prior to the change-in-control; (iii)&nbsp;a reduction in </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>124</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=127,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=590717,FOLIO='124',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EK10601A.;12',USER='DHOLBRO',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ek10601_1_125"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>base
salary, or failure to increase base salary each year in a percentage amount at least equal to that of the consumer price index; (iv)&nbsp;a reduction in the named executive's total compensation
to a level below the average total compensation paid by the Company to the named executive during the 24&nbsp;months prior to the change-in-control; or (v)&nbsp;any change
in job duties requiring relocation outside of the greater metropolitan area of the primary work location without the employee's written consent. In addition, Mr.&nbsp;Rotella's agreement further
defines "good reason" to include (a)&nbsp;the failure of a successor to the Company to assume all of our obligations under the agreement and any related arrangement; or (b)&nbsp;a material breach
of the agreement by the Company or its successor. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
other named executives other than Ms.&nbsp;Chapman, "good reason" is generally defined as any of the following: (i)&nbsp;the assignment of duties which (a)&nbsp;are materially
different from the executive's duties immediately prior to the change-in-control, or (b)&nbsp;result in the executive having significantly less authority and/or
responsibility than he or she had prior to the change-in-control; (ii)&nbsp;a reduction of executive's total compensation opportunity from that in effect on the date of the
change-in-control, with the exception that changes in the allocation of the executive's compensation between salary and incentive compensation, and changes to the criteria or
method for determining incentive compensation amounts actually earned, shall not constitute "good reason"; or (iii)&nbsp;a relocation by more than 50 miles of the executive's principal place of
employment as in effect on the date of the change-in-control, if the relocation increases the distance between the executive's principal residence and principal place of
employment by more than 25 miles. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
amount we would owe Ms.&nbsp;Chapman if we terminated her for any reason other than her material breach of the terms of her severance or consulting agreement does not change
whether or not a change-in-control occurs. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Within Three Years after a Change-in-Control of the Company: Termination by the Named Executive without Good Reason  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If the named executive terminates his or her employment without "good reason" within three years after a change-in-control, the employment
and change-in-control agreements and plan documents and, for Ms.&nbsp;Chapman, her severance and consulting agreements, do not provide for any additional compensation or
benefits. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> 280G Tax Gross-Up  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our employment and change-in-control agreements with named executives other than Ms.&nbsp;Chapman provide that if any Company payment
made upon termination after a change-in-control of the Company constitutes an "excess parachute payment" under Section&nbsp;280G of the Code, we would make a
gross-up payment to the named executive. The gross-up payment would be equal to the amount necessary to cause the net amount retained by the named executive, after subtracting
(i)&nbsp;the excise tax imposed on "excess parachute payments" by Section&nbsp;4999 of the Code, and (ii)&nbsp;any federal, state and local income taxes, FICA tax, and the Section&nbsp;4999
excise tax on the gross-up payment, to be equal to the net amount the named executive would have retained had no Section&nbsp;4999 excise tax been imposed and no Company
gross-up payment been made. Ms.&nbsp;Chapman's severance agreement does not provide for any gross-up payment. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Post-Employment Recoupment of Equity Awards  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The award agreements for restricted stock and stock option grants made in 2006 and beyond to employees, including the named executives, contain certain
non-solicitation restrictions that generally apply for one-year after termination of the named executive's employment with us. If the named executive violates the
non-solicitation provisions, he or she will forfeit all of his or her outstanding stock options and restricted stock awarded under the agreement. In addition, the named executive </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>125</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=128,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=576383,FOLIO='125',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EK10601A.;12',USER='DHOLBRO',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ek10601_1_126"> </A>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>would
be required to return to us all gains realized by him or her on restricted stock or stock options obtained pursuant to the agreements during the 12&nbsp;month period prior to his or her
violation. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I><U>Kerry K. Killinger</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Mr.&nbsp;Killinger's
employment agreement provides for a lump sum cash payment in the amount of three times his "annual compensation," as described at
page&nbsp;122, in the event (i)&nbsp;we terminate his employment, without cause, prior to a change-in-control; or (ii)&nbsp;if within three years following a
change-in-control, our successor terminates his employment for any reason or by Mr.&nbsp;Killinger for good reason.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Mr.&nbsp;Killinger's
employment agreement provides for the acceleration of vesting of stock options and restricted stock upon his termination (i)&nbsp;by us for any
reason other than for cause preceding a change-in-control, or (ii)&nbsp;after a change-in-control, by our successor for any reason or by
Mr.&nbsp;Killinger for good reason (assuming the vesting of his options and stock does not accelerate on the closing of the change-in-control). The value of stock option
vesting reflected in the table is zero as none of his unvested options has an exercise price less than the $13.61 closing price of our stock on December&nbsp;31, 2007. Because Mr.&nbsp;Killinger
meets the age and service requirements for retirement under his stock option agreements (age 55 with 10&nbsp;years of service), his post-termination exercise period for vested options is
5&nbsp;years, not to exceed the original expiration date of the option grant.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(3)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
value of restricted stock vesting was calculated by multiplying the number of unvested shares by $13.61, with any performance measures through the end of 2007
factored into the calculation for Death or Disability but not for a Change-in-Control.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(4)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>This
reflects the anticipated payout rate for performance share awards with uncompleted performance cycles as of December&nbsp;31, 2007.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(5)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Mr.&nbsp;Killinger's
employment agreement provides that if any Company payments made upon termination after a change-in-control of the Company
constitute a "parachute payment" under Section&nbsp;280G of the Code, the Company would make a gross-up payment to Mr.&nbsp;Killinger. The gross-up payment would be equal
to the amount necessary to cause the net amount retained by Mr.&nbsp;Killinger, after subtracting (i)&nbsp;the parachute payment excise tax imposed by Section&nbsp;4999 of the Code, and
(ii)&nbsp;any federal, state and local income taxes, FICA tax, and the Section&nbsp;4999 excise tax on the gross-up payment, to be equal to the net amount Mr.&nbsp;Killinger would
have retained had no Section&nbsp;4999 excise tax been imposed and no Company gross-up payment been made.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(6)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
addition to the total values payable to Mr.&nbsp;Killinger upon each of the triggering events contained in this table, Mr.&nbsp;Killinger would have been
entitled to receive or retain the following amounts, none of which would have increased or </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>126</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=129,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=26102,FOLIO='126',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EK10601A.;12',USER='DHOLBRO',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ek10601_1_127"> </A>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>accelerated
on his termination or a change-in-control of the Company: (i)&nbsp;all of his vested stock options reported at page&nbsp;108, unless he is terminated for cause;
(ii)&nbsp;his accrued benefits under our nonqualified deferred compensation plans, as reported at page&nbsp;118, unless in the case of the SERP and SERAP he is terminated for cause;
(iii)&nbsp;his accrued benefits under the WaMu Pension Plan, as reported at page&nbsp;114, and unless he is terminated for cause, his accrued benefits under the ETRIP, as reported in footnote 3 to
the Pension Benefits Table at page&nbsp;114; (iv)&nbsp;his accrued benefits or amounts under Company plans that do not discriminate in favor of executive officers and that are available generally
to all salaried employees, such as the WaMu Savings (401(k)) Plan; and (v)&nbsp;the deferred bonus arrangement described on page&nbsp;120. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the aggregate of these
amounts was $19,972,267, or $8,986,004 if Mr.&nbsp;Killinger had been terminated for cause. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(7)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>These
columns assume that the vesting of stock options and restricted stock accelerated on the consummation of the change-in-control because the
Human Resources Committee did not provide for the assumption or substitution of unvested stock options and restricted stock by the acquiring company.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(8)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Note:
For a change-in-control and subsequent termination of Mr.&nbsp;Killinger's employment, he would have received the "Total Value Upon
Event" specified in the table in column C plus the "Total Value Upon Event" in either column D or column E, depending upon the circumstances of his termination.&#151; </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>127</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Mr.&nbsp;Casey's
change-in-control agreement provides for a lump sum cash payment in the amount of three times his "annual compensation," as
described at page&nbsp;122, if within three years following a change-in-control, our successor terminates his employment without cause or if Mr.&nbsp;Casey terminates his
employment for good reason. In addition, his agreement contains provision that prohibits him from soliciting our employees, contractors or consultants to join one of our competitors, which would apply
for one-year after termination of his employment. The amount shown in Column B represents payments we would have made under our new executive severance plan assuming it had been effective
at December&nbsp;31, 2007.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
value of stock option vesting reflected in the table is zero as none of the unvested options has an exercise price less than the $13.61 closing price of our stock
on December&nbsp;31, 2007.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(3)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
value of restricted stock vesting was calculated by multiplying the number of unvested shares by $13.61, with any performance measures through the end of 2007
factored into the calculation for Death or Disability but not for a Change-in-Control.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(4)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>This
reflects the anticipated payout rate for performance share awards with uncompleted performance cycles as of December&nbsp;31, 2007.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(5)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Mr.&nbsp;Casey's
change-in-control agreement provides that if any Company payments made upon termination after a
change-in-control of the Company constitute a "parachute payment" under Section&nbsp;280G of the Code, our successor would make a gross-up payment to
Mr.&nbsp;Casey. The gross-up payment would be equal to the amount necessary to cause the net amount retained by Mr.&nbsp;Casey, after subtracting (i)&nbsp;the parachute payment
excise tax imposed by Section&nbsp;4999 of the Code, and (ii)&nbsp;any federal, state and local income taxes, FICA tax, and the Section&nbsp;4999 excise tax on the gross-up payment,
to be equal to the net amount Mr.&nbsp;Casey would have retained had no Section&nbsp;4999 excise tax been imposed and no Company gross-up payment been made.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(6)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
addition to the total values payable to Mr.&nbsp;Casey upon each of the triggering events contained in this table, Mr.&nbsp;Casey would have been entitled to
receive or retain the following amounts, none of which would have increased or accelerated on his termination or a change-in-control of the Company: (i)&nbsp;all of his
vested stock options reported at page&nbsp;108, unless he is terminated for cause; (ii)&nbsp;his accrued benefits under our nonqualified deferred compensation plans, as reported at
page&nbsp;118, unless in the case of the SERP and SERAP he is terminated for cause, (iii)&nbsp;his accrued benefits under the WaMu Pension Plan, as reported at page&nbsp;114, and unless he is
terminated for cause his accrued benefits under the ETRIP, as reported in footnote 3 to the Pension Benefits Table at page&nbsp;114; (iv)&nbsp;his 2007 Leadership Bonus Plan cash bonus payout; and
(v)&nbsp;his accrued benefits or amounts under Company plans that do not discriminate in favor of executive officers and that are available generally to all salaried employees, such as the WaMu
Savings (401(k)) Plan. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the aggregate of these amounts was $5,145,839, or $3,210,630 if Mr.&nbsp;Casey had been terminated for cause. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>128</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=131,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=904525,FOLIO='128',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EM10601A.;12',USER='DCONRAD',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:13' -->
<A NAME="page_em10601_1_129"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(7)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>These
columns assume that the vesting of stock options and restricted stock accelerated on the consummation of the change-in-control because the
Human Resources Committee did not provide for the assumption or substitution of unvested stock options and restricted stock by the acquiring company.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(8)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><I>Note</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=1>:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For a change-in-control and subsequent termination of Mr.&nbsp;Casey's
employment, he would have received the "Total Value Upon Event" specified in the table in column C plus the "Total Value Upon Event" in either column D or column E, depending upon the circumstances of
his termination. </FONT></DD></DL>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Stephen J. Rotella  </I></B></FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Mr.&nbsp;Rotella's
employment agreement provides for a lump sum cash payment in the amount of (i)&nbsp;two times his "annual compensation," as described at
page&nbsp;122, in the event the Company terminates his employment, without cause, prior to a change-in-control; and (ii)&nbsp;three times his annual compensation if within
three years following a change-in-control, his employment is terminated by the Company for any reason or by Mr.&nbsp;Rotella for good reason.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Mr.&nbsp;Rotella's
employment agreement provides for the acceleration of vesting of stock options and restricted stock upon his termination (i)&nbsp;by the Company
for any reason other than for cause preceding a change-in-control, or (ii)&nbsp;after a change-in-control, by the Company for any reason or by
Mr.&nbsp;Rotella for good reason (assuming the options and stock does not accelerate on the closing of the change-in-control). In addition, upon such terminations,
Mr.&nbsp;Rotella would continue to hold his performance share awards for all uncompleted performance cycles. Such awards would pay out at the end of the applicable cycles in accordance with the
terms of the Performance Share Award Program. The value of stock option vesting reflected in the table is zero as none of the unvested options has an exercise price less than the $13.61 closing price
of our stock on December&nbsp;31, 2007.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(3)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
value of restricted stock vesting was calculated by multiplying the number of unvested shares by $13.61, with any performance measures through the end of 2007
factored into the calculation for Death or Disability but not for a Change-in-Control.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(4)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>This
reflects the anticipated payout rate for performance share awards with uncompleted performance cycles as of December&nbsp;31, 2007.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(5)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Mr.&nbsp;Rotella
was 50% vested in his SERP benefit as of the end of 2007. This amount represents the portion of Mr.&nbsp;Rotella's SERP benefit that would become
non-forfeitable upon his death or permanent disability. There is no incremental value to Mr.&nbsp;Rotella in other termination situations.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(6)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Mr.&nbsp;Rotella's
employment agreement provides that if any Company payments made upon termination after a change-in-control of the Company
constitute a "parachute payment" under Section&nbsp;280G of the Code, the Company would make a gross-up payment to Mr.&nbsp;Rotella. The gross-up payment would be equal to
the amount necessary to cause the net </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>129</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=132,EFW="2185889",CP="WASHINGTON MUTUAL, INC",DN="1",CHK=978516,FOLIO='129',FILE='DISK131:[08ZBU1.08ZBU10601]EM10601A.;12',USER='DCONRAD',CD='21-MAY-2008;23:13' -->
<A NAME="page_em10601_1_130"> </A>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>amount
retained by Mr.&nbsp;Rotella, after subtracting (i)&nbsp;the parachute payment excise tax imposed by Section&nbsp;4999 of the Code, and (ii)&nbsp;any federal, state and local income
taxes, FICA tax, and the Section&nbsp;4999 excise tax on the gross-up payment, to be equal to the net amount Mr.&nbsp;Rotella would have retained had no Section&nbsp;4999 excise tax
been imposed and no Company gross-up payment been made. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(7)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
addition to the total values payable to Mr.&nbsp;Rotella upon each of the triggering events contained in this table, Mr.&nbsp;Rotella would have been entitled to
receive or retain the following amounts, none of which would have increased or accelerated on his termination or a change-in-control of the Company: (i)&nbsp;all of his
vested stock options reported at page&nbsp;108, unless he is terminated for cause; (ii)&nbsp;his accrued benefits under our nonqualified deferred compensation plans, as reported at
page&nbsp;118, unless in the case of the SERP he is terminated for cause; (iii)&nbsp;his accrued benefits under the WaMu Pension Plan, as reported at page&nbsp;114 and his accrued benefits under
the ETRIP, as reported in footnote 3 to the Pension Benefits Table at page&nbsp;114, in each case unless he is terminated for cause; (iv)&nbsp;his 2007 Leadership Bonus Plan cash bonus payout; and
(v)&nbsp;his accrued benefits or amounts under Company plans that do not discriminate in favor of executive officers and that are available generally to all salaried employees, such as the WaMu
Savings (401(k)) Plan. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the aggregate of these amounts was $15,465,672, or $13,495,795 if Mr.&nbsp;Rotella had been terminated for cause.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(8)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Under
Mr.&nbsp;Rotella's employment agreement, he would be required to execute a separation agreement with the Company upon termination to receive the benefits
reported in this column. The separation agreement would contain a 24&nbsp;month non-competition and non-solicitation covenant in favor of the Company.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(9)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Mr.&nbsp;Rotella's
employment agreement provides that the Human Resources Committee may exclude any of his particular awards of restricted stock made after
March&nbsp;1, 2005 from acceleration upon the triggering event reported in this column.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(10)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>These
columns assume that the vesting of stock options and restricted stock accelerated on the consummation of the change-in-control because
the Human Resources Committee did not provide for the assumption or substitution of unvested stock options and restricted stock by the acquiring company.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><SUP>(11)</SUP></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Note:
For a change-in-control and subsequent termination of Mr.&nbsp;Rotella's employment, he would have received the "Total Value Upon
Event" specified in the table in column D plus the "Total Value Upon Event" in either column E or column F, depending upon the circumstances of his termination. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>James B. Corcoran  </I></B></FONT></P>
